Posts.Content: Oct 9, 2009 02:45PM NANPAR wrote: Hello to all, Thank you all for the quick response.  Our first meeting with the oncologist was this morning and we left the hospital with a dilema.  We were under the impression (after our last appointment with the surgeon) that she would have to go through radiation treatments. Imagine our surprise this morning when the oncologist said that she she doesn't really need radiation therapy.  We were told that according to the pathology results she already has a 96% chance that her bc won't return.  This was based upon the following facts, her age - 72 , her tumor having been 1.5cm in size and no spread to the lymph nodes.  If she were to follow the radiation treatment (16 week treatment) it would increase her survival rate to 99%.  Since my mom's health is fragile and sufffers from other serious health problems the oncologist feels she doesn't need to be put through the gruelling process for only an additional 3% chance it won't come back. In other words the risks of her feeling worse or getting sicker during treatment outways the overall benefit.  However, the choice is still my mom's and she can choose to go through the treatment.  My mom's got the next month to make her decision since treament cannot start until she's had an MRI of her spinal vertabraes and a bone density test which will determine which drug to put her on for the next 5 years.  Should we be looking at this as a blessing or a curse?  Has anyone else gone through this?

If she were to follow the radiation treatments (16 week treatment) it would increase her survival rate to 99%.  Since my mom's health is fragile and sufffers from other serious health problems the oncologist feels she doesn't need to be put through the gruelling process for only an additional 3% chance of  it not coming back.  In other words the risks of radiation therapy outways the benefits (for her).
